title: Private Law and Contract Enforcement in the United States and France
description: Offered in Paris, France. Parties engaging in economic exchange often organize their relationships through contracts and other private legal structures. The organization of exchange and the body of law and private institutions that govern and influence its structure. Substantive theoretical component and practical component, with on-site modules at the International Court of Commercial Arbitration in Paris. A comparative legal and institutional approach will be maintained throughout. Prerequisite: ECON 121 (Intermediate Microeconomics), MATH 112 (Calculus of Functions of One Variable I), or permission of instructor. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited. Application Deadline: February 15. Students are responsible for arranging travel to and from Paris and all other expenses beyond tuition. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Credits: 2. Tuition: $7,600. Course Dates: June 26 - July 28.
